name: 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)phenylacetic acid
Reason: 3,5-Bis(trifluoromethyl)phenylacetic acid has a melting point that we can compare to benzene, which has a melting point of 5°C. The trifluoromethyl functional group introduces a significant dipole moment, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +50°C. The additional fluorine atoms also contribute to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, with an approximate increase of +10°C per atom, totaling +30°C. The carboxylic acid group introduces a hydrogen bonding potential, raising the melting point by approximately +10°C. The presence of two phenyl groups contributes to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, with an approximate increase of +20°C per group, totaling +40°C.
